patient.name: Melinda Hamilton

demographics.livingSituation: Shares a two-bedroom apartment with fiancé in Owensboro, KY
supportSystem: Two close college friends (biweekly video calls)

psychosocialHistory.trauma: Complex trauma history including emotional neglect in childhood and sexual assault at age 19.
psychosocialHistory.therapyExperience: Completed 18 months of therapy focused on anxiety/trauma during graduate school; resumed care last month after symptom flare.
psychosocialHistory.substanceUse: Social alcohol use (1-2 drinks on weekends); denies other substances.
psychosocialHistory.medical: PCOS managed with metformin, migraines controlled with lifestyle modifications.

strengths: Insightful and reflective about emotional patterns
Motivated to use coping strategies when prompted
currentStressors: Wedding planning logistics and financial strain
Contact from estranged mother triggering trauma reminders

encounter.signatureStatus: Electronically signed by Michelle Craig at 11/04/2025 10:14 AM

session.observation: ATTITUDE TOWARDS THERAPY: good. MOTIVATION: good; identified need to resume therapy. COPING ABILITY: fair; acknowledges pausing some coping, implementing helpful alternatives. STRESSORS/TRIGGERS: anxiety, depression, recent change, trauma history. HYGIENE: good. CAFFEINE: none. SLEEP: good.
subjectiveHighlights: Client noticed resurgence of trauma dreams tied to upcoming visit with estranged mother.
Reports journaling three evenings this week which reduced bedtime rumination.
Requested support staying present with fiancé instead of withdrawing during conflict.
recentWins: Completed high-stakes work presentation despite anticipatory anxiety.
Set boundaries limiting phone calls with mother to 15 minutes.
Practiced grounding twice during nightmare awakenings and returned to sleep.

symptomSnapshot.mood: Baseline anxiety 6/10 with spikes to 9/10 at night; sadness brief (1-2 hrs) without hopelessness.
symptomSnapshot.sleep: Falls asleep within 25 minutes; trauma dreams 3 nights this week but able to re-ground.
symptomSnapshot.appetite: Stable; denies emotional eating or restriction.
symptomSnapshot.energy: Moderate afternoon fatigue, improved with breaks and hydration.

interventionsUsed: Solution-focused scaling questions to gauge progress since previous session.
Narrative re-authoring exercise reframing caregiver expectations.
Psychoeducation on window of tolerance and somatic cues.

assigned: Track anxiety triggers using mood journal app
Practice grounding with textured object or ice cube nightly
homeworkReview.completion: Completed journaling 4/7 nights; grounding practiced 3/7 nights; avoidance noted when planning ran late.
homeworkReview.barriers: Client forgets grounding until anxiety escalates; competing evening demands from wedding planning.

mse.narrative: Appearance: Grooming WNL; Posture/Gait WNL; Activity decreased. Sensory: Attention WNL; Concentration WNL; Orientation WNL. Memory WNL. Relating: Eye contact WNL; Facial expression WNL; Affect congruent. Mood: anxious; Speech WNL. Thought Process goal-directed; Thought Content WNL. Insight fair; Judgement fair.

protectiveFactors: Commitment to fiancé and younger sister
Active engagement in therapy and coping practice

assessment.riskAssessment: Denies SI/HI. No psychosis. Passive thoughts previously; no plan or intent. Protective factors include engagement in therapy and social reconnection. Risk remains low; continue monitoring.

symptomSummary.anxiety: Persistent generalized worry with somatic tension yet increased use of grounding and self-monitoring tools.
symptomSummary.trauma: Re-emergent triggers linked to family contact; dream frequency indicates nervous system activation that client can now down-regulate.
symptomSummary.mood: Low mood episodes brief and responsive to behavioral activation; denies vegetative symptoms.
symptomSummary.adhd: Maintains benefit from ADHD compensatory strategies (timers, task chunking).

assessment.progressSinceLast: Client demonstrates more insight into trauma triggers, greater use of coping tools, and willingness to set family boundaries. Anxiety remains moderate but less impairing than last month.
assessment.substanceUse: Occasional wine with dinner; no cravings or misuse.

plan.frequency: biweekly sessions; reassess and titrate as needed.
upcomingFocus: Integrate trauma narrative work with compassion-focused reframing
Solidify sensory-based grounding routine for nighttime anxiety
Role-play communication strategies with fiancé around emotional check-ins
homework: Schedule two 20-minute creativity blocks this week for grounding
Use window of tolerance worksheet to label physiological cues

treatmentPlan.frequency: biWeekly Sessions, reassess continually titrate as needed.

goals.summary: Goal #1: Improve overall self-worth and self-esteem — Objective: create positive self-talk to replace negative self-talk. Tx Modality: CBT, Solution Focused Theory, Narrative Theory, Motivational Interviewing. Progress: Fair as evidenced by maintaining her positive self-talk.

Goal #2: Work on dealing with boredom and idle time — Objective: identify coping strategies other than staying busy to manage idle time. Tx Modality: CBT, Solution Focused Theory, Narrative Theory, Motivational Interviewing. Progress: Fair as evidenced by increased motivation and broader coping tools.

Goal #3: Understand Autism diagnosis — Objective: evaluate the overall impact of Autism on daily functioning. Tx Modality: CBT, Solution Focused Theory, Narrative Theory, Motivational Interviewing. Progress: Fair as evidenced by researching supportive strategies.

treatmentPlan.prognosis: Fair given the willingness to make changes, past help with therapy, possible underlying trauma and if client can build trust and rapport to address the underlying trauma.

previousNote.subjective: Client reported increased worry surrounding recent transitions and occasional sleep disruption. Noted benefit from journaling and music. Denied SI/HI. Identified tension with family as primary stressor and desire to re-establish routines.

objective.mse: Appearance neat; behavior cooperative; speech normal rate/volume; mood anxious, affect congruent; thought process goal-directed; no delusions/hallucinations; orientation intact; insight/judgment fair.

assessment.risk: No current SI/HI; low risk with protective factors including engagement in therapy and supportive sister.

goals: Increase use of cognitive restructuring for worry episodes.
Rebuild daily routine with two consistent sleep anchors by next session.
Process trauma-linked triggers using narrative techniques.
plan.frequency: Biweekly sessions; reinforce coping; revisit sleep plan.
homework: Track anxiety spikes with ABC worksheet

signature.attestation: I discussed this case with the treating therapist and agree with the assessment and plan.
I have staffed this case with the therapist and I agree with the interventions, progress, and approach presented. I have reviewed and approved this note.
